title: Do you realize that since the Universe is itself is an immensely powerful computer, that it must be conscious? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: Do you realize that since the Universe is itself is an immensely powerful computer, that it must be conscious? I think I know where you’re coming from, but that’s still a bit of a nonsense on several levels. The universe may or may not be a computer (like the Earth is in Douglas Adam’s book), a device employed for computation. It’s basically a religious claim. Do you have evidence? Until you show some, I’m skeptical of your claim. Yes, all, well, let’s be pedantic and say most, systems with behaviors obeying rules (e.g. natural laws) can be thought of in terms of computation. Rocks falling down obey rules, and can be thought of as computational elements, and under specific circumstances they can actually do computation. But that doesn’t make them a computer. There’s a vague equivalence, and some people promote this to a metaphysical position of algorithmic idealism, but that’s more of an opinion. Not everything that does some computation is a computer. Rain falling down can be viewed as doing addition. But that doesn’t make it a computer. A calculator does computation, but it’s not a computer. The universe can be thought of as a giant heap of calculators. Still not a computer. Nor does computational capacity automatically create consciousness. The sum of all computers on the internet have a computational power far exceeding what’s needed for consciousness, yet it’s not conscious (as far as anyone can tell, you could claim it does, and it would also be merely a claim, less religious, because it’s more testable). On the other hand, considering that a human is considered conscious, even though only a small portion produces consciousness (e.g. you’re equally conscious if your limbs are amputated). With a bit of a stretch it could be said that a single human surviving in the universe would make the entire universe conscious. The stars and galaxies contributing as much as fingernails or hair to the consciousness. With that in mind, the universe may have a multiple personality disorder, and with all the asylums, it’s insane too, and very confused. The idea isn’t new, and if you had not stated it as a fact, it would merely be “not a new idea”. The way you phrased it, it’s religion. Don’t get me wrong, the universe COULD be a computer and whether it is or not, it COULD be conscious, but I doubt you have the data to justify claiming it IS one. Equally, the universe COULD be simulated, or it COULD be thought into existence by an “entity”, or it COULD be a “physical” system. Occam favours the last one. But, it’s not possible to distinguish between those possibilities. They behave identically. What’s worse, well, look at solipsism.

The mere fact that we exist and tout our intelligence as having arisen from its own non-existence should be the cause for a lot of consternation when assuming anything about that which we are not necessarily the author of. Whether the universe thinks in the same manner as we do, by using words or pictures to demarcate its own unfolding to itself, or whether all of its many possibilities are spread our across what we call time (much like a move, frame by frame of celluloid) who is to know? Definitely not us. We perceive thought to be sequential, but what if it is actually simultaneous in a potential that we are incapable of envisioning except as that which is unknowable. We need to accept our place in this schemata and quit trying to quantify our responsibility to ourselves by conjecture that is not relevant to us.

Q. Do you realize that since the Universe is itself is an immensely powerful computer, that it must be conscious? Consciousness according to: The DAVIES Hypothesis - YouTube is defined as the state of mind of a ‘brain’ working in the three dimensions of time. These are ‘real’ time, which equates to the present, giving us continuous updates on environment and circumstances. ‘unreal’ time, the past, allows access to the database of our knowledge via memory. and ‘imaginary’ time, the future, collating information from the others to arrive at thoughts or solutions. Human brains (and many creatures) function accordingly but what about computers? Human knowledge, say, passed down through the generations, derives from as far back as our single cell origin. I suggest you can’t build that into a computer.

The question contains a non-sequitur. It does not follow that an immensely powerful computer must be conscious. It may be that the universe, however powerful a computer it turns out to be, is not the kind of computer that can be sentient. What you need is positive evidence of that sentience before a belief in it is warranted. So no, I do not realise that because there is not sufficient evidence to support the realisation.
